Module filters.py¶

modules.filters.chromosome_filter(path_input, name)¶

With this filter we obtain the labels/titles for each cromosome of our file, e.g., in Leishmania case we’ll obtain the labels “LinJ.01”, “LinJ.02”, etc.

The objective of this function is to be able to correctly name the files since programming languages do not usually admit a non-string format, numbers that start at 0, in this way we can automate their correct labeling, especially for numbers from 01 to 09 .

Parameters

  • path_input (string) – Path to the .fasta file to read.

  • name (string) – Name to give the results. In Leishmania’s case, it’s “LinJ”.

Returns

a python list with the chosen labels

Return type

Pytho List

modules.filters.dash_filter(path_input, writing_path_input)¶

With this function, we’ll filter all the “-” dashes in the sequences.

modules.filters.filter_by_column(path_input, column, size_filter, writing_path_input)¶

This function will filter a CSV data depending on length (if we want to firlter by sequence length) or percent (if we want to filter by identity percent).

Parameters

  • path_input (string) – Path to the CSV file we want to filter data.

  • column (string) – Can be length (if we want to firlter by sequence length) or percent (if we want to filter by identity percent)

  • size_filter (integer) – Number to filter dependint of the column argument.

  • writing_path_input (string) – Path to the CSV file this function will create and save

Returns

A CSV file with the dalta filtered depending on the column and size_filter argumetns.

Return type

CSV file

modules.filters.global_filters_main(path_input, writing_path_input, genome_fasta, naming_short, max_diff)¶

This function mixes every other filter made. Each one writes a CSV which is overwritten every time till the final step.
